title: 114_hr5606
content: The Act is titled the "Anti-terrorism Information Sharing Is Strength Act" and focuses on information sharing. Section 314 of the USA PATRIOT Act is amended to include specified unlawful activities in addition to terrorist acts and money laundering activities. Section 314 of the USA PATRIOT Act is updated to include specified unlawful activities, in addition to terrorist acts and money laundering activities. This amendment aims to enhance information sharing to combat illicit financing while preventing inappropriate dissemination of information. Federal law enforcement agencies and regulators, as well as financial institutions, should share information about terrorist activities, money laundering, and specified unlawful activities to combat illicit financing. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE LIABILITY. Amends Section 5318(g)(3)(B) of title 31, United States Code to include a duty for financial institutions and their personnel to demonstrate good faith in making disclosures. SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to specific committees within 120 days of the Act's enactment on the risks and benefits of sharing information between US financial institutions and foreign entities. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on whether certain financial institutions should be allowed to share information under the USA PATRIOT Act if they voluntarily establish and maintain an anti-money laundering program that meets regulatory standards. Information properly classified under criteria established by the President must be submitted separately in a classified annex to the committees, and can also be provided as a briefing at an appropriate security level upon request by the chairman or ranking Member of the committees. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to align with the amendments made.
